meanings.def: to look, smile, etc. in a particular direction
examples: cast something + adv./prep. She cast a welcoming smile in his direction.
I cast an angry look at him.
He groaned, casting his eyes to the ceiling.
cast somebody something She cast me a disapproving glance.

meanings.def: to make light, a shadow, etc. appear in a particular place
examples: cast something Someone was standing in the dark shadow cast by the light.
cast something + adv./prep. The moon had cast a silvery light on the huts.
The setting sun cast an orange glow over the mountains.

meanings.def: to say, do or suggest something that makes people doubt something or think that somebody is less honest, good, etc.
examples: cast something on/upon something This latest evidence casts serious doubt on his version of events.
cast something ‘You know that I'm not one to cast aspersions,’ he said.
cast something over something The sad news cast a shadow over the proceedings (= made people feel unhappy).
cast something into something The entire economic future of the islands was cast into doubt.
Her aim was clearly to to cast suspicion upon their motives.
The allegations are casting a cloud over his re-election campaign.
The incident had cast a pall over their preparations for the World Cup.

meanings.def: to vote for somebody/something
examples: He refused to cast a vote for either candidate.
How many of the registered voters will actually cast their ballots?

meanings.def: to choose actors to play the different parts in a film, play, etc.; to choose an actor to play a particular role
examples: cast something The play is being cast in both the US and Britain.
cast somebody (as somebody) He has cast her as an ambitious lawyer in his latest movie.

meanings.def: to describe or present somebody/yourself in a particular way
examples: cast somebody/yourself as something He cast himself as the innocent victim of a hate campaign.
cast somebody/yourself in something The press were quick to cast her in the role of the ‘other woman’.

meanings.def: to throw one end of a fishing line into a river, etc.
to throw somebody/something somewhere, especially using force
examples: The priceless treasures had been cast into the Nile.
They cast anchor at nightfall.

meanings.def: when a snake casts its skin, the skin comes off as part of a natural process
if a horse casts a shoe, the shoe comes off by accident
to shape hot liquid metal, etc. by pouring it into a hollow container (called a mould)
examples: a statue cast in bronze
(figurative) an artist cast in the mould of (= very similar to) Miró

meanings.def: to look at or examine something quickly
examples: Could you just run your eyes over this report?
I cast my eyes around the room but couldn't see any familiar faces.

meanings.def: to make a problem, etc. easier to understand
examples: Recent research has cast new light on the causes of the disease.

meanings.def: to make a problem, etc. easier to understand
examples: Recent research has thrown new light on the causes of the disease.

meanings.def: to make yourself think about something that happened in the past
examples: I want you to cast your minds back to the first time you met.

meanings.def: to consider a lot of different people, activities, possibilities, etc. when you are looking for something
examples: It’s worth casting your net wide when applying for your first job.

meanings.def: to use words that are thought to be magic and have the power to change or influence somebody/something
used to say that an event has happened or a decision has been made that cannot be changed

to use a method of choosing somebody/something that involves putting a number folded pieces of paper in a bag, one of them with a mark on it. People then take it in turns to take a piece of paper from the bag and the one who takes the paper with the mark on it is chosen.
examples: They drew lots for the right to go first.

meanings.def: to stop caring about how dangerous something might be; to start taking risks
examples: He threw caution to the wind and dived into the water after the child.

idioms.idiom: cast/run an eye/your eyes over something
idioms.def: to look at or examine something quickly
examples: Could you just run your eyes over this report?
I cast my eyes around the room but couldn't see any familiar faces.

idioms.def: to make a problem, etc. easier to understand
examples: Recent research has cast new light on the causes of the disease.

idioms.def: to make a problem, etc. easier to understand
examples: Recent research has thrown new light on the causes of the disease.

idioms.def: to make yourself think about something that happened in the past
examples: I want you to cast your minds back to the first time you met.

idioms.def: to consider a lot of different people, activities, possibilities, etc. when you are looking for something
examples: It’s worth casting your net wide when applying for your first job.

idioms.def: to use words that are thought to be magic and have the power to change or influence somebody/something
used to say that an event has happened or a decision has been made that cannot be changed

to use a method of choosing somebody/something that involves putting a number folded pieces of paper in a bag, one of them with a mark on it. People then take it in turns to take a piece of paper from the bag and the one who takes the paper with the mark on it is chosen.
examples: They drew lots for the right to go first.

idioms.def: to stop caring about how dangerous something might be; to start taking risks
examples: He threw caution to the wind and dived into the water after the child.

meanings.def: all the people who act in a play or film
examples: an all-star cast (= including many well-known actors)
the supporting cast (= not the main actors, but the others)
The whole cast performs/perform brilliantly.
in the cast Everyone in the cast is excellent.
Bonus features include interviews with the cast and crew.
a play with a large cast of characters
None of the other cast members makes much of an impression.
members of the cast
the cast list
The film has a great cast.
The ensemble cast is strong.
Only one of the original cast reappears.
The rest of the cast doesn't have much to do.
The director has secured outstanding performances from the entire cast.

meanings.def: an object that is made by pouring hot liquid metal, etc. into a mould (= a container with a particular shape)
a container with a particular shape used to make an object
the way that a person or thing is or appears
examples: He has an unusual cast of mind.
I disliked the arrogant cast to her mouth.
The colours he wore emphasized the olive cast of his skin.

meanings.def: an act of throwing something, especially a fishing line
a case made of plaster of Paris that covers a broken bone and protects it
examples: in a cast Her leg's in a cast.
